main_section.name: Konstantin Abramkin
main_section.description: I create interactive 3D experiences on the web.
main_section.subtitle: The beginning is always the moment of the finest balance. Every master of the web knows this. To study the path of the Web Developer, first place it in sequence: HTML, CSS, JavaScript. And then ‚Äî build interactive worlds and three-dimensional stories. Place it in space: the Universe of the Web, where every line of code is like a detective trail, leading wherever your imagination takes you. And do not be deceived by the thought that your years have passed, or that school failed to teach you enough ‚Äî just act. And then you discover true weapons: React, Node.js, and Three.js; the world of interactive maps with Mapbox; animations powered by Framer Motion or GSAP. And the modern Web reveals itself as a living world ‚Äî one where the architect is you.

skills_section.title: Skills
skills_section.3d:
I have been doing 3D modeling for a long time ‚Äî at first more as a hobby. Lately, however, I have immersed myself much deeper in study and practice to bring my ideas to life. In the CGBoost Cubic Worlds course and several Udemy lessons, I gained practical skills: environment modeling, basic shader creation, animation, character rigging, and much more.

Right now I feel that in this field almost nothing is impossible for me ‚Äî all I need is time and a good idea.

On my blog, I‚Äôve prepared full-length articles with step-by-step instructions for modeling Cubic Worlds ‚Äî from the very first steps to building complete 3D scenes. You‚Äôre welcome to explore them here: My Cubic Worlds blog.
skills_section.three_js:
For over 4 years, I have been deeply engaged in both the theory and practice of Three.js. The most valuable learning experiences came from the Simon Bruno ‚Äì Journey to Three.js course and the unique materials by WawaSensei (both public on YouTube and private), which covered a wide range of techniques and approaches in creating 3D applications.

I also expanded my knowledge of low-level WebGL and experimented with shaders, which still feel somewhat magical to me. Another area of strong interest is working with physics: I have experience with Rapier, as well as Cannon.js and Ammo.js.

The biggest breakthrough for me was discovering React Three Fiber and React Drei ‚Äî tools that significantly simplify building 3D scenes in React and enable fast experimentation. During this time, I have created many pet projects and experiments, and through practice I realized that what excites me the most is creating 3D environments and games.

I also explored Unity and Babylon.js, but my love for JavaScript and the ease of working with React Three Fiber always brought me back. I believe that web-based games and interactive 3D experiences still hold a tremendous future.

Here you can also check out my latest Three.js examples.
skills_section.three_js_examples: Past projects hosted on other sites, not featured here
skills_section.backend_data: I‚Äôve been working with Node.js practically since the start of my frontend career. I build lightweight backend services and APIs, and set up data storage and access across different databases‚Äîfrom document-oriented (MongoDB/JSON) to relational (SQL). Although backend isn‚Äôt my primary focus, I take on these tasks when there‚Äôs no one to delegate them to. On the frontend, I have strong hands-on experience with caching and offline mode: I actively use IndexedDB (in combination with service workers), enabling the application to work fully offline as long as synchronization is configured correctly. For state management, I have extensive experience with RxJS in Angular and Redux in both Angular and React; however, within the React ecosystem I prefer Zustand for its simplicity and because it‚Äôs sufficient for 100% of my use cases (Redux is used where it‚Äôs truly justified).
skills_section.visual_data:
I have extensive experience visualizing large datasets (8,000+ records) as interactive charts and tables. My primary tool is D3.js: I‚Äôve implemented synchronized multiple charts, zooming, tooltips/popups, custom icons, animations, and line and pie charts. I‚Äôve worked with other libraries as well, but I consider D3.js the best choice: it doesn‚Äôt lock you into a specific style and gives full freedom for features, though it can require more effort to implement.

For tables, I primarily use AG Grid‚Äîexcellent documentation, a wide feature set, support for Angular/React/Vanilla JS/TS, and easy integration of custom components. I‚Äôve implemented sorting, drag-and-drop, and custom filters, among others. With AG Grid, I displayed data for about 8,000 fields and two-way synchronized selection and search with the map‚Äîeverything ran fast and reliably.
skills_section.front_end:
I‚Äôve been ‚Äúmarried‚Äù to JavaScript for nine years now‚Äîand I‚Äôve never regretted the choice. Before that, I experimented with Java, PHP, C++, C#, and Python, but each time I ran into the feeling of being tied to a specific platform or set of features. JavaScript gave me what I was missing‚Äîfreedom: at any moment I can change direction without a full reset‚ÄîFrontend, Backend, GameDev, ML/Machine Learning, Mobile, Desktop, Arduino/Robotics.

Yes, there are trade-offs‚ÄîJS can trail compiled languages in performance‚Äîbut the ecosystem rapidly covers most needs. That‚Äôs where TypeScript‚Äîmy second professional ‚Äúlove‚Äù‚Äîhas my back: it makes code transparent and predictable (the any type now appears only in nightmares), and scaling becomes much simpler.

I‚Äôve spent years working with Vue, Angular, and React; today my default choice is React. Paired with TypeScript, this stack lets me design reliable, scalable systems‚Äîfrom the UI to complex client-side logic and backend integrations.
skills_section.ui:
When I entered the web development world, the market was firmly dominated by Bootstrap. I never quite understood why: yes, before flexbox it offered a convenient grid system, but the design always felt outdated to me. On top of that, any deviation required adding ‚Äúhacks,‚Äù since there was no flexible API at the time.

Later, Material Design appeared ‚Äî more visually appealing, but even harder to customize than Bootstrap.

In recent years, Tailwind has emerged, and it‚Äôs exactly what was missing: it doesn‚Äôt impose a specific style, is fully customizable, well-optimized for bundling, and noticeably simplifies development. With Tailwind, I rarely write ‚Äúpure‚Äù CSS anymore ‚Äî most of my work is done with utility classes directly in the markup.

On top of that, many UI libraries have been built around Tailwind; one of my favorites for its simplicity is shadcn/ui. Overall, I have extensive experience working with Bootstrap, Material, and Tailwind.
skills_section.map:
I have been working with maps professionally for 4‚Äì5 years. My first real experience began at the company Kernel. At first, I didn‚Äôt even think I would enjoy this field so much, but after solving a few complex tasks related to calculating the overall geometry of multiple polygons (essentially the convexHull algorithm, which I didn‚Äôt even know about back then), I was completely hooked. I could ride the trolleybus and sketch algorithms on a fogged-up window, lost in thought. It was incredibly exciting.

We worked with ArcGIS, since the company had been building solutions on that platform for many years, so there wasn‚Äôt much choice. Our main challenge was to display 8,000 fields quickly and without delays. Essentially, we were creating something very similar to Cropio. After two years, when much had already been done, I managed to convince my colleagues to switch to Mapbox. It gave us the speed and interactivity we desperately needed. However, Mapbox lacked some of the ArcGIS features, such as raster functions, so my task was to combine both technologies. We succeeded brilliantly.

Today, I have solid experience with both Mapbox and ArcGIS, though I personally prefer Mapbox for its simplicity and reliability. I have a strong understanding of Mapbox expressions, know how to integrate data from OpenStreetMap and ArcGIS, and how to add 3D objects to the map.

In my own pet projects, I rarely use maps ‚Äî I don‚Äôt often come up with ideas for web apps involving them, and those experiments tend to remain rather superficial. But when I work with maps in real-world tasks, I get drawn in completely ‚Äî just like in childhood, when I was absorbed by Total War games or books about explorers like Francis Drake, James Cook, or Magellan. When building maps, I feel like both a pirate and a discoverer.

map_content.title: Some of My Map Projects
map_content.population_project: Project on Visualizing the Population of Ukraine

experience.title: Experience
experience.kernel:
At Kernel, I worked for 5 years, where I built two full-fledged web applications from scratch:
  • a global interactive map of all fields by clusters (over 8,000 polygons);
  • a detailed analytics system for a specific field.
    In these projects we combined:
  • Mapbox ‚Äî for rendering geometry and interactive graphics;
  • ArcGIS ‚Äî for working with raster data: NDVI imagery, soil tiles, work-order tracks.
    The functionality covered:
  • analytics for each field;
  • polygon calculations and processing (including hand-drawn ones);
  • comparison of key metrics;
  • comprehensive agri-analytics tools for agronomists.
Technologies: Angular 2+, D3.js, Turf.js, ArcGIS, Mapbox, AG Grid, Material UI.
Unfortunately, I cannot share any visuals or links because the project was an internal solution for company employees, and I signed a non-disclosure agreement (NDA). In short, it was a full-fledged alternative to Cropio: in some ways less large-scale, yet more innovative in certain aspects.
experience.u_studio: I‚Äôve been working at Ustudio for the past two years. I independently developed the frontend of an application from scratch to display destroyed and rebuilt assets during the war in Ukraine. Implemented a heat map of funding levels and needs, filters by asset types, analytical charts, and detailed cards for each asset. Tools used: React, Node.js (caching and data processing), Mapbox, Material UI, Tailwind CSS, Redux, D3.js, Framer Motion, IndexedDB (frontend caching). Project link.
experience.ixlayer:
At ixlayer, I worked remotely for over two years.
  • Built websites with Vue.js for genetic DNA testing services.
  • Primary focus ‚Äî landing pages, registration forms, and questionnaires/forms.
Technologies: Vue.js.
experience.computools: The first company where I began working as a web developer was Computools. My primary responsibilities included building interactive, animated websites using HTML, SCSS, JavaScript, and Bootstrap, as well as gaining my first hands-on experience with Angular 2.
experience.about_game:
Friend, if you‚Äôve reached this section‚Äîwe‚Äôre already on the same wavelength. I‚Äôve reached the point where I know enough to bring my dream to life. Cubic Worlds Game is my first official game, which I plan to develop over the coming months‚Äîand possibly years‚Äîuntil it becomes a full-fledged project.

In Cubic Worlds I‚Äôm building not just a game but an entire world: you‚Äôll be able to defend a village from hordes of skeletons and zombies; brew potions and tinctures; unlock magical abilities by reading spellbooks; and shapeshift into different kinds of animals and birds. Find and collect weapons (swords, rifles, staves), clothing, and items; store them in your own home and sell them at the market. On your journeys you‚Äôll meet friends and enemies who will either help you or get in your way. Planned features include rooms for online play with friends or random players, as well as various types of transport: cars, robots, planes, helicopters (depending on the world).

The core idea is not only to complete quests but also to learn. Depending on the room, the game will explain scientific approaches, physics, mathematics, English, logic, algorithms, programming, history, and more‚Äîso the game is both engaging and useful.

What‚Äôs already done: a basic character controller; a world editor (you can ‚Äúpaint‚Äù grass, soil, and other objects onto surfaces); adding individual items and physics; user-linked saves; the character can perform basic attacks and break crates. Next up: enemies, item drops, and other mechanics.

Planning to build your own world? Then head here.

If you‚Äôd like to support the development, have an interesting project for me, or want to collaborate‚Äîwrite to me. I‚Äôll be glad to cooperate, hear your ideas, and get feedback. Below I‚Äôll attach links to my social media and Patreon. Thanks for reading‚Äîsee you! üòä

u_studio.description: Development of a national platform for restoration. Visualization of destroyed objects on the map, integration of investor data. Complex dashboards with React and Mapbox.

cubic_worlds_game.description: Creation of a self-developed RPG game in the browser. React Three Fiber, physical bodies, shaders. Caching assets through IndexedDB for performance.

kernel.title: Kernel - AgroTech Digitalization
kernel.description: Digitalization of fields: 8000+ polygons, analysis of soil and tracking of machinery. Development of high-load maps with TableGrid and custom layers.

ixlayer.title: ixLayer - DNA Testing Platform
ixlayer.description: Development of interfaces for DNA testing. Vue.js components, integration of medical APIs. Visualization of test results and optimization of medical work processes.

computools.description: Development of web interfaces on HTML, CSS, JS. Transition to creating SPAs on Angular and TypeScript. Optimization of UI/UX, work in an Agile team.

map_dream.intro: The DREAM ecosystem is a digital platform for Ukraine's recovery. My role was to create the main module for displaying geodata.

dashboard_fields.intro: Central control panel for the head agronomist of the holding.

telematics.description: Isometric diagram demonstrating the concept of telematics in smart agriculture. Shows various agricultural operations and digital monitoring systems with connected machinery and control features.

mapping.description: Software interface for monitoring agricultural machinery on a map. Displays machine tracks, different field types, and a timeline for analyzing operations.

crop_status.description: Interface for monitoring crop status with a data table and satellite map. Shows information about sown and harvested areas for different crops.

ndvi.description: Satellite map with color-coded overlay displaying NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index) for analyzing plant health and growth stages across the field.

passport_field.intro: Digital twin of each company field with a 10-year history.

ixlayer_landing.intro: Series of high-load marketing pages for telemedicine in the USA.
